22533364 Genome-wide association study using 1,471 genotyped participants from the Framingham Heart Study, of which 1,173 individuals had known lifespans, plus 517 individuals from the Offspring cohort for validating connections between longevity and genetic variants A total of 27 SNPs, including in CDH4, SVEP1, CACNA1C, CARS, STK24, C7orf50, PARVG, NCAM2, PPP2R2C, NLRC5, BTBD9, RAC2, TGFA, KIAA0649, ABCC4, CLSTN2, FAM19A5 and RUNX3, were identified at the intersection of various statistical procedures
+
 rs10149689Ashkenazi Jewish CEP128 G/AAGhet0.085
Substitution frequency (GnomAD)0.40768443933
Pubmed ID Study design Conclusions
19837933 TSH heritability, its distribution, and association with SNPs in the TSH-B and TSHR genes was determined in Ashkenazi Jewish centenarians (n = 232; median age, 97 yr), their offspring (n = 366; median age, 69 yr), and age-matched controls without familial longevity (n = 163; median age, 70 yr) A heritable phenotype characterized by raised serum TSH is associated with human longevity. Allele frequency of two SNPs in the promoter/enhancer region of TSHR gene (rs12050077 and rs10149689), associated with increased serum TSH, was higher in centenarians and their offspring compared to controls.
Gene Description (CEP128)Involved in protein localization. Located in centriole and spindle pole. Part of centriolar subdistal appendage. [provided by Alliance of Genome Resources, Apr 2022]
+
 rs12050077Ashkenazi Jewish CEP128 A/GGAhet0.085
Substitution frequency (GnomAD)0.408222591362
Pubmed ID Study design Conclusions
19837933 TSH heritability, its distribution, and association with SNPs in the TSH-B and TSHR genes was determined in Ashkenazi Jewish centenarians (n = 232; median age, 97 yr), their offspring (n = 366; median age, 69 yr), and age-matched controls without familial longevity (n = 163; median age, 70 yr) A heritable phenotype characterized by raised serum TSH is associated with human longevity. Allele frequency of two SNPs in the promoter/enhancer region of TSHR gene (rs12050077 and rs10149689), associated with increased serum TSH, was higher in centenarians and their offspring compared to controls.
Gene Description (CEP128)Involved in protein localization. Located in centriole and spindle pole. Part of centriolar subdistal appendage. [provided by Alliance of Genome Resources, Apr 2022]
+
 rs2149954European LINC02227 T/CCThet0.085
Substitution frequency (GnomAD)0.361480439785
Pubmed ID Study design Conclusions
24688116 A genome-wide association meta-analysis was performed in 7729 long-lived individuals of European descent (>=85 years) and 16,121 younger controls ( <65 years) followed by replication in an additional set of 13,060 long-lived individuals and 61 156 controls. rs2149954 and rs4420638 were observed significantly associated with longevity. Meta-analysis showed rs2149954 (T) associates with increased survival.
+
 rs4646Italian (Salerno) CYP19A1 C/AAChet0.09
cDNA changec.*161T>G
Substitution frequency (GnomAD)0.677687366508
Pubmed ID Study design Conclusions
20819792 The association of ESR1 (PvuII and XbaI) and CYP19 (rs4646) polymorphisms with longevity was examined in a sample of 258 individuals (mean age = 83.1 ± 5.7 years). Based on mortality data over 9 years, the sample was divided into two groups of participants surviving more than 90 years or not. ESR1 PP (odds ratio = 2.2) and CYP19 genotypes carrying the T allele (odds ratio = 1.9) were significantly associated with longevity (survival to age more than 90 years)
Gene Description (CYP19A1)This gene encodes a member of the cytochrome P450 superfamily of enzymes. The cytochrome P450 proteins are monooxygenases which catalyze many reactions involved in drug metabolism and synthesis of cholesterol, steroids and other lipids. This protein localizes to the endoplasmic reticulum and catalyzes the last steps of estrogen biosynthesis. Mutations in this gene can result in either increased or decreased aromatase activity; the associated phenotypes suggest that estrogen functions both as a sex steroid hormone and in growth or differentiation. Alternative promoter use and alternative splicing results in multiple transcript variants that have different tissue specificities. [provided by RefSeq, Dec 2016]
+
 rs2498804Dutch LOC107987209 A/CCAhet0.095
cDNA changec.471-32C>A
Substitution frequency (GnomAD)0.389224641596
Pubmed ID Study design Conclusions
21418511 Genome-wide association study in 403 unrelated nonagenarians from long-living families and 1670 younger controls. Strongest candidates were then investigated in a meta-analysis of 4149 nonagenarian cases and 7582 younger controls. rs2498804 in AKT1 also showed a significant association with survival into old age
Gene Description (LOC107987209)This gene encodes an E3 ubiquitin ligase that regulates cell cycle progression, cell proliferation and apoptosis. The N-terminus of this protein binds to the cytoplasmic tail of the CD27 antigen, a member of the tumor necrosis factor receptor (TNFR) superfamily. In response to UV radiation-induced DNA damage, this protein has been shown to mediate the ubiquitination of proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA), an important step in translesion DNA synthesis. [provided by RefSeq, Sep 2018]
+
 rs3906146American (Caucasian) LMX1B T/CCThet0.1
cDNA changec.*4883C>T
Substitution frequency (GnomAD)0.469839142091
Pubmed ID Study design Conclusions
22279548 Genome-wide association study in 801 centenarians and 914 healthy controls 281 SNPs were found to discriminate between cases and controls
Gene Description (LMX1B)This gene encodes a member of LIM-homeodomain family of proteins containing two N-terminal zinc-binding LIM domains, 1 homeodomain, and a C-terminal glutamine-rich domain. It functions as a transcription factor, and is essential for the normal development of dorsal limb structures, the glomerular basement membrane, the anterior segment of the eye, and dopaminergic and serotonergic neurons. Mutations in this gene are associated with nail-patella syndrome. Alternatively spliced transcript variants encoding different isoforms have been found for this gene. [provided by RefSeq, Mar 2010]
+
 rs73598374Italian (Central) ADA T/CCThet0.115
cDNA changec.22G>A
Substitution frequency (GnomAD)0.0586286154313
ID Association Population Identifier Gene Pubmed ID
1201 significant Italian (Central) rs73598374 ADA 21865054 other
Pubmed ID Study design Conclusions
21865054 Functional SNPs have been determined for 1071 unrelated healthy individuals (502 males and 569 females) from Central Italy, 18-106 years old, divided into three gender-specific age classes defined according to demographic information and accounting for the different survivals between sexes. The categories for men were: individuals <66 years old, individuals 66-88 years old, and individuals > 88 years old. The categories for women were: individuals <73 years old, individuals 73-91 years old, and individuals > 91 years old. Single-locus analysis showed that when comparing all 3 age categories only ADA 22G>A (rs73598374) is significantly associated with human life-expectancy in males
21865054 Functional SNPs have been determined for 1071 unrelated healthy individuals (502 males and 569 females) from Central Italy, 18-106 years old, divided into three gender-specific age classes defined according to demographic information and accounting for the different survivals between sexes. The categories for men were: individuals <66 years old, individuals 66-88 years old, and individuals > 88 years old. The categories for women were: individuals <73 years old, individuals 73-91 years old, and individuals > 91 years old. When comparing all 3 age groups, both two-loci and three-loci interaction are significantly associated with life-expectancy in males. For females, a significant two-loci interaction occurs in females between ADA 22G>A (rs73598374) and TNF-a 238G>A (rs361525) only when comparing young and mid-aged individuals.
Gene Description (ADA)This gene encodes an enzyme that catalyzes the hydrolysis of adenosine to inosine in the purine catabolic pathway. Various mutations have been described for this gene and have been linked to human diseases related to impaired immune function such as severe combined immunodeficiency disease (SCID) which is the result of a deficiency in the ADA enzyme. In ADA-deficient individuals there is a marked depletion of T, B, and NK lymphocytes, and consequently, a lack of both humoral and cellular immunity. Conversely, elevated levels of this enzyme are associated with congenital hemolytic anemia. [provided by RefSeq, Sep 2019]
+
 rs7799039Jordanian LOC105375494 A/GGAhet0.115
Substitution frequency (GnomAD)0.370785440613
Pubmed ID Study design Conclusions
20201642 SNPs rs266729 (-11377G/C), rs2241766 (+45T/G), and rs1501299 (+276 G/T) of adiponectin gene (ADIPQO) and rs7799039 (-2548C/A) SNP of leptin (LEP) gene were genotyped in 110 randomly selected elderly subjects (>85 years old) with mean age of 90.2 years, and 120 young control subjects (range from 20 to 50 years) with mean age of 32.0 years No significant differences were detected in the genotype and allele frequencies of examined gene variants between the two groups (p > 0.05). However, when gender was considered, genotypes and alleles frequencies of rs1501299 SNP in ADIPOQ gene and rs7799039 in LEP gene were significantly associated with longevity in men (p < 0.02) but not in women (p > 0.05).
+
 rs7656234American (Caucasian) SLC4A4 T/CCThet0.185
cDNA changec.1974+3411C>T
Substitution frequency (GnomAD)0.590667775361
Pubmed ID Study design Conclusions
22279548 Genome-wide association study in 801 centenarians and 914 healthy controls 281 SNPs were found to discriminate between cases and controls
Gene Description (SLC4A4)This gene encodes a sodium bicarbonate cotransporter (NBC) involved in the regulation of bicarbonate secretion and absorption and intracellular pH. Mutations in this gene are associated with proximal renal tubular acidosis. Multiple transcript variants encoding different isoforms have been found for this gene. [provided by RefSeq, Oct 2008]

Gene Description (CTNNA3)This gene encodes a protein that belongs to the vinculin/alpha-catenin family. The encoded protein plays a role in cell-cell adhesion in muscle cells. Mutations in this gene are associated with arrhythmogenic right ventricular dysplasia, familial 13. Alternative splicing results in multiple transcript variants. [provided by RefSeq, Mar 2014]

Involved in negative regulation of Arp2/3 complex-mediated actin nucleation; regulation of neuron migration; and regulation of neuron projection development. Located in cytoplasm. Implicated in complex cortical dysplasia with other brain malformations. [provided by Alliance of Genome Resources, Apr 2022]

Gene Description (CTNNA2)Enables actin filament binding activity.  rs1860242American (Caucasian) CTNND2 G/AAGhet0.205
cDNA changec.2788+13539T>C
Substitution frequency (GnomAD)0.740380320337
Pubmed ID Study design Conclusions
22279548 Genome-wide association study in 801 centenarians and 914 healthy controls 281 SNPs were found to discriminate between cases and controls
Gene Description (CTNND2)This gene encodes an adhesive junction associated protein of the armadillo/beta-catenin superfamily and is implicated in brain and eye development and cancer formation. The protein encoded by this gene promotes the disruption of E-cadherin based adherens junction to favor cell spreading upon stimulation by hepatocyte growth factor. This gene is overexpressed in prostate adenocarcinomas and is associated with decreased expression of tumor suppressor E-cadherin in this tissue. This gene resides in a region of the short arm of chromosome 5 that is deleted in Cri du Chat syndrome. Alternative splicing results in multiple transcript variants encoding different isoforms. [provided by RefSeq, Dec 2013]

Longevity drugs

Plenty of drugs are frequently prescribed at an older age. Moreover, some drugs are known to have geroprotective action (e.g. statins, metformin, rapamycin, etc.). Drug metabolism to a large extent depends on a person’s genetic polymorphisms, affecting the activity of xenobiotics-transforming enzymes. So it’s a common situation when individual dose correction is needed, or even another drug has to be taken in order to avoid adverse effects. Longevity-drugs report is mainly based on data from PharmGKB database ( https://www.pharmgkb.org/ ) and DrugAge.

In the table you can find data about your genome’s gene variants, associated with a changed response to the drugs.

Drugs Report

Major risks

It is not enough to have "centenarian" genes to become one: You have to cut down Your health risks before. This section contains information about the risk of developing chronic age-related diseases: cardiovascular, cancer, mental health, chronic inflammation, bone and muscle diseases, and lung diseases.

Cancer Report

+
# ChromPositionGeneRSIDcDNA ChangeZygosity Allele FrequencyPhenotype NameSignificance
+
1chr8 31064419WRN rs2230009 c.340G>TNoneNone Werner syndromeUncertain significance
This gene encodes a member of the RecQ subfamily of DNA helicase proteins. The encoded nuclear protein is important in the maintenance of genome stability and plays a role in DNA repair, replication, transcription and telomere maintenance. This protein contains a N-terminal 3' to 5' exonuclease domain, an ATP-dependent helicase domain and RQC (RecQ helicase conserved region) domain in its central region, and a C-terminal HRDC (helicase RNase D C-terminal) domain and nuclear localization signal. Defects in this gene are the cause of Werner syndrome, an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by accelerated aging and an elevated risk for certain cancers. [provided by RefSeq, Aug 2017]
+
2chr19 45351661ERCC2 rs13181 c.2251A>TNone3.99456738835e-06 not providedUncertain significance
The nucleotide excision repair pathway is a mechanism to repair damage to DNA. The protein encoded by this gene is involved in transcription-coupled nucleotide excision repair and is an integral member of the basal transcription factor BTF2/TFIIH complex. The gene product has ATP-dependent DNA helicase activity and belongs to the RAD3/XPD subfamily of helicases. Defects in this gene can result in three different disorders, the cancer-prone syndrome xeroderma pigmentosum complementation group D, trichothiodystrophy, and Cockayne syndrome. Alternatively spliced transcript variants encoding different isoforms have been found for this gene. [provided by RefSeq, Aug 2008]
+
3chr17 7676154TP53 rs1042522 c.215C>TNoneNone Li-Fraumeni syndromeUncertain significance
This gene encodes a tumor suppressor protein containing transcriptional activation, DNA binding, and oligomerization domains. The encoded protein responds to diverse cellular stresses to regulate expression of target genes, thereby inducing cell cycle arrest, apoptosis, senescence, DNA repair, or changes in metabolism. Mutations in this gene are associated with a variety of human cancers, including hereditary cancers such as Li-Fraumeni syndrome. Alternative splicing of this gene and the use of alternate promoters result in multiple transcript variants and isoforms. Additional isoforms have also been shown to result from the use of alternate translation initiation codons from identical transcript variants (PMIDs: 12032546, 20937277). [provided by RefSeq, Dec 2016]
+
4chr16 13934224ERCC4 rs1799802 c.1135C>TNone0.00409443794534 Xeroderma pigmentosum, group F|Fanconi anemia complementation group Q|Cockayne syndrome|not specified|not providedConflicting interpretations of pathogenicity
The protein encoded by this gene forms a complex with ERCC1 and is involved in the 5' incision made during nucleotide excision repair. This complex is a structure specific DNA repair endonuclease that interacts with EME1. Defects in this gene are a cause of xeroderma pigmentosum complementation group F (XP-F), or xeroderma pigmentosum VI (XP6).[provided by RefSeq, Mar 2009]
+
5chr13 109782884IRS2 rs1805097 c.3170G>ANone0.341208943453 DIABETES, TYPE II, SUSCEPTIBILITY TOrisk factor
This gene encodes the insulin receptor substrate 2, a cytoplasmic signaling molecule that mediates effects of insulin, insulin-like growth factor 1, and other cytokines by acting as a molecular adaptor between diverse receptor tyrosine kinases and downstream effectors. The product of this gene is phosphorylated by the insulin receptor tyrosine kinase upon receptor stimulation, as well as by an interleukin 4 receptor-associated kinase in response to IL4 treatment. [provided by RefSeq, Jul 2008]
+
6chr12 132626230POLE rs5745066 c.6418G>CNone3.18712401896e-05 Colorectal cancer, susceptibility to, 12Uncertain significance
This gene encodes the catalytic subunit of DNA polymerase epsilon. The enzyme is involved in DNA repair and chromosomal DNA replication. Mutations in this gene have been associated with colorectal cancer 12 and facial dysmorphism, immunodeficiency, livedo, and short stature. [provided by RefSeq, Sep 2013]
+
7chr12 12718165CDKN1B rs2066827 c.326T>CNone1.6086351535e-05 Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 4Uncertain significance
This gene encodes a cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor, which shares a limited similarity with CDK inhibitor CDKN1A/p21. The encoded protein binds to and prevents the activation of cyclin E-CDK2 or cyclin D-CDK4 complexes, and thus controls the cell cycle progression at G1. The degradation of this protein, which is triggered by its CDK dependent phosphorylation and subsequent ubiquitination by SCF complexes, is required for the cellular transition from quiescence to the proliferative state. Mutations in this gene are associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type IV (MEN4). [provided by RefSeq, Apr 2014]
+
8chr12 12718165CDKN1B rs2066827 c.326T>ANone0.00016086351535 Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 4|Hereditary cancer-predisposing syndromeConflicting interpretations of pathogenicity
This gene encodes a cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor, which shares a limited similarity with CDK inhibitor CDKN1A/p21. The encoded protein binds to and prevents the activation of cyclin E-CDK2 or cyclin D-CDK4 complexes, and thus controls the cell cycle progression at G1. The degradation of this protein, which is triggered by its CDK dependent phosphorylation and subsequent ubiquitination by SCF complexes, is required for the cellular transition from quiescence to the proliferative state. Mutations in this gene are associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type IV (MEN4). [provided by RefSeq, Apr 2014]
+
9chr11 108289623ATM rs1800058 c.4258C>TNone0.0111928723443 Hereditary breast ovarian cancer syndrome|Malignant tumor of breast|Ataxia-telangiectasia syndrome|Hereditary cancer-predisposing syndrome|not specified|Breast and/or ovarian cancer|not providedConflicting interpretations of pathogenicity
The protein encoded by this gene belongs to the PI3/PI4-kinase family. This protein is an important cell cycle checkpoint kinase that phosphorylates; thus, it functions as a regulator of a wide variety of downstream proteins, including tumor suppressor proteins p53 and BRCA1, checkpoint kinase CHK2, checkpoint proteins RAD17 and RAD9, and DNA repair protein NBS1. This protein and the closely related kinase ATR are thought to be master controllers of cell cycle checkpoint signaling pathways that are required for cell response to DNA damage and for genome stability. Mutations in this gene are associated with ataxia telangiectasia, an autosomal recessive disorder. [provided by RefSeq, Aug 2010]
+
10chr11 108272604ATM rs3092859 c.3150T>CNone0.00153906028871 Malignant tumor of breast|Ataxia-telangiectasia syndrome|Hereditary cancer-predisposing syndrome|not specified|Breast and/or ovarian cancer|not providedConflicting interpretations of pathogenicity
The protein encoded by this gene belongs to the PI3/PI4-kinase family. This protein is an important cell cycle checkpoint kinase that phosphorylates; thus, it functions as a regulator of a wide variety of downstream proteins, including tumor suppressor proteins p53 and BRCA1, checkpoint kinase CHK2, checkpoint proteins RAD17 and RAD9, and DNA repair protein NBS1. This protein and the closely related kinase ATR are thought to be master controllers of cell cycle checkpoint signaling pathways that are required for cell response to DNA damage and for genome stability. Mutations in this gene are associated with ataxia telangiectasia, an autosomal recessive disorder. [provided by RefSeq, Aug 2010]

Coronary artery Disease

+
# RSIDGeneRisk AlleleGenotypePubmed ID PopulationP-ValueWeight
+
1 rs8055236 CDH13 G G/GPMID 17554300; PMID 19956433; PMID 20017983;European [PMID 17554300]: 6 x 10-6-1.7
Conclusion: CDH13 encodes T-cadherin, is a regulator of vascular wall remodeling, angiogenesis and is essential for adiponectinвЂ™s vascular actions. GG genotype was shown to have increased risk for heart disease; the odds ratio is 2.23 (CI 1.56-3.17). [PMID 17554300]. There was no statistically significant association with CHD in the Chinese population [PMC4509238].
Study design: [PMID 17554300]: Discovery ancestry (country of recruitment): 4864 European (U.K.); Discovery sample description: 1,926 European ancestry cases, 2,938 European ancestry controls;
+
2 rs599839 SORT1 A A/APMID: 32858814; PMID 33321069; PMID: 17634449; PMID 18262040; PMID 19380133; PMID 19660754; PMID 19750184;European [PMID 33321069]: 2 x 10-7-1.2
Conclusion: NPs in PSRC1 that have regulatory potential may affect CAD risk by altering CELSR2, PSRC1, and SORT1 gene expression and circulating granulins and apolipoprotein B proteins [PMID: 35252377]. Gene product regulate apoB secretion and LDL catabolism. rs599839 is a SNP found to be associated with heart disease by the German MI (Myocardial infarction) Family Study group, over several populations. The odds ratio for the (common) risk allele, rs599839(A), is 1.29 (CI: 1.18-1.40, adjusted p=0.0006). Your genotype (AA) is associated with 1.4x increased risk for heart disease [PMID 17634449]
Study design: [PMID 33321069]: Discovery ancestry (country of recruitment): 16817 South Asian (Pakistan), 49826 European (Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Italy, Netherlands, Sweden, U.K., NR, U.S.); Discovery sample description: 19,245 European ancestry cases, 8,463 South Asian ancestry cases, 30,581 European ancestry controls, 8,354 South Asian ancestry controls; Replication sample description16,704 European ancestry cases, 101,083 European ancestry controls
+
3 rs964184 ZPR1 G G/GPMID 19060906; PMID 20864672; PMID 21378990; PMID 22003152; PMID 21378990; PMID 28714975;European [PMID 28714975]: 5 x 10-6; [PMID 21378990]: 1 x 10-17;-1.2
Conclusion: rs964184 variant in the ZPR1 gene has been associated with blood lipids levels both in fasting and postprandial state and with the risk of myocardial infarction and CAD. GG genotype was shown to has an increased risk of hypertriglyceridemia and coronary arthery disease. In a study [PMID: 35782928] it was shown, that G-allele carriers can benefit from low-fat diet, better than by a Mediterranean diet.
Study design: [PMID 21378990]: Discovery ancestry (country of recruitment): 86995 European (NR); Discovery sample description: 22,233 European ancestry cases, 64,762 European ancestry controls; [PMID 28714975]: Discovery ancestry (country of recruitment): 63731 European, NR (U.K.); Discovery sample description: 18,467 European and unknown ancestry cases, 45,264 European and unknown ancestry controls;
+
4 rs1122608 LDLR G G/GPMID: 27664493; PMID 23380588; PMID 23202125; PMID 20810930; PMID 19956433; PMID: 33321069; PMID 21378990;European; Asian [PMID: 33321069]: 5 x 10-7; [PMID 21378990]: 1 x 10-9-1.0
Conclusion: It has been reported that rs1122608 adjacent to low-density lipoprotein cholesterol receptor (LDLR) locus is associated with the risk of coronary artery disease (CAD) and blood lipid profile. A statistically significant association was identified between rs1122608-G allele and CAD risk in European and Asian subgroups [PMID: 27664493]. Your genotype (GG) is associated with increased risk for coronary arthery disease.
Study design: [PMID: 33321069]: Discovery ancestry (country of recruitment)16817 South Asian (Pakistan), 49826 European (Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Italy, Netherlands, Sweden, U.K., NR, U.S.); Discovery sample description19,245 European ancestry cases, 8,463 South Asian ancestry cases, 30,581 European ancestry controls, 8,354 South Asian ancestry controls; [PMID 21378990]: Discovery ancestry (country of recruitment)86995 European (NR); Discovery sample description22,233 European ancestry cases, 64,762 European ancestry controls
+
5 rs383830 APC A A/APMID 26436499; PMID 17554300; PMID 21804106; PMID 19956433; PMID 21804106;European -0.9
Conclusion: APC is a tumor suppressor gene that is involved in the processes of cell migration and adhesion, transcriptional activation, and apoptosis. rs383830 has been reported to be associated with heart disease, in particular, coronary artery disease. The risk allele is (A); the odds ratio associated with AA genotype is 1.92 (CI 1.40-2.63), which corresponds to 1.9x risk. [PMID 17554300].
Study design: [PMID 17554300]: Discovery sample description: 1,926 European ancestry cases, 2,938 European ancestry controls: Discovery ancestry (country of recruitment): 4864 European (U.K.)
+
6 rs1746048 CXCL12 (LINC02881) C C/CPMID: 28614256; PMID 19956433; PMID 23531450; PMID 21378990; PMID 33632238; PMID 21378990;European; Asian [PMID 33632238]: 1 x 10-6; [PMID 21378990]:3 x 10-10;-0.9
Conclusion: The meta-analysis of 48,852 patients and 64,386 controls from 12 studies showed that patients with rs1746048 had 1.11 times of high risk in developing CHD (ORвЂЉ=вЂЉ1.11; 95% CIвЂЉ=вЂЉ1.09вЂ“1.14; PвЂЉ<вЂЉ.005; I2вЂЉ=вЂЉ35.8%). The increased risk of CHD was also found in both Asian (ORвЂЉ=вЂЉ1.07; 95%CIвЂЉ=вЂЉ1.02вЂ“1.12; PвЂЉ<вЂЉ.005; I2вЂЉ=вЂЉ40.6%) and Caucasian populations (ORвЂЉ=вЂЉ1.14; 95% CIвЂЉ=вЂЉ1.10вЂ“1.18; PвЂЉ<вЂЉ.005; I2вЂЉ=вЂЉ22.2%) [PMID: 28614256]. CC carriers has 1,1 - 1,3x increased risk for coronary heart disease
Study design: [PMID 21378990]: Discovery ancestry (country of recruitment): 86995 European (NR); Discovery sample description: 22,233 European ancestry cases, 64,762 European ancestry controls
+
7 rs12413409 CNNM2 G G/GPMID 21378988; PMID 24262325; PMID: 21378990; PMID: 31228190; PMID 21378990;European [PMID 21378990]: 1 x 10-9-0.8
Conclusion: CNNM2 gene affects the risk of coronary heart disease. G-allele is associated with increased risk of coronary disease. The rs7692387 risk (G) allele was associated with higher incidence of major CVD events. In two major primary CVD prevention trials, aspirin was found to confer a significant (21%) reduction in risk of major CVD amongst the 66% of participants who were homozygous for the rs7692387 risk (G) allele [PMID: 31228190].
Study design: [PMID 21378990]: Discovery ancestry (country of recruitment): 86995 European (NR); Discovery sample description: 22,233 European ancestry cases, 64,762 European ancestry controls
+
8 rs515135 APOB T T/TPMID 23202125; PMID: 30507093; PMID 29212778European -0.7
Conclusion: APOB is a large glycoprotein that plays an important role in the metabolism of lipoproteins in the human body. Small changes in the structure and function of APOB can cause major problems in lipid metabolism. Large-scale association analysis identifies rs515135 as a risk loci for coronary artery disease. T-carriers has an increased risk of coronary arthery disease. Also the association of T-allele frequency and familiar hypercholesterolemia was found.
Study design: [PMID 29212778]: Discovery ancestry (country of recruitment): 547261 NR (U.K., NR); Discovery sample description: up to 122,733 cases, up to 424,528 controls
+
9 rs3184504 SH2B3 T T/TPMID 24262325; PMID 21378990; PMID 26343387;Multiethnic [PMID 26343387]: 1 x 10-9-0.7
Conclusion: SH2B adaptor protein 3 (SH2B3) is a negative regulator of multiple cytokine signaling pathways and is associated with increased risk of myocardial infarction (MI) and fibrosis [PMID: 25628389]. TT variant according to GWAS studies is associated with increased risk of CAD.
Study design: [PMID 26343387]: Discovery ancestry (country of recruitment): 141217 European (Finland, Sweden, U.S., Iceland, Italy, Netherlands, Greece, Germany, U.K., Spain, Estonia, NR, Republic of Ireland), 25557 South Asian (India, U.K., Pakistan), 2268 Greater Middle Eastern (Middle Eastern, North African or Persian) (NR), 4095 Hispanic or Latin American (U.S.), 3139 African American or Afro-Caribbean (U.S.), 11323 East Asian (Republic of Korea, China); Discovery sample description: 42,096 European ancestry cases, 361 African American cases, 758 Hispanic American cases, 12,658 South Asian ancestry cases, 1,802 Lebanese ancestry cases, 3,614 East Asian ancestry cases, 99,121 European ancestry controls, 2,778 African American controls, 3,337 Hispanic American controls, 12,899 South Asian ancestry controls, 466 Lebanese ancestry controls, 7,709 East Asian ancestry controls; [PMID 32469254]: Discovery ancestry (country of recruitment): 340799 East Asian, European (NR), 51442 East Asian (Japan); Discovery sample description: 15,302 Japanese ancestry cases, 76,014 European and East Asian ancestry cases, 36,140 Japanese ancestry controls, 264,785 European and East Asian ancestry controls.

Conclusion: PCSK9 overexpression increases plasma LDL-C levels by downregulating LDL receptor (LDLR) expression after transcription. TT variant carriers has elevated risk of coronary arthery disease.

Conclusion: Polymorphisms in MTHFD1L, including rs6922269, have been implicated in risk for coronary artery disease (CAD). GA genotype is associated with 1.2x risk of coronary artery disease

Cardio Hereditary

Timely detection and diagnosis of heart disorders can lead to enhanced treatment options, help to prevent sudden cardiac death, and improve prognosis. This report analyzes the most relevant genes for arrhythmias, congenital heart disease, and cardiomyopathies. Analyzed gene abnormalities may cause the following syndromes: Long and short QT, Brugada syndrome, catecholaminergic polymorphic ventricular tachycardia, cardiomyopathies dilated and hypertrophic, and congenital heart defects. In addition, this panel includes vascular abnormalities, such as dolichoectasia and hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia.

Hereditary cardiovascular diseases

+
# GenersIDcDNA changeYour genotypeSequence ontologySIFT prediction Allele FrequencyPhenotype NameSignificanceClinVar IDOMIM
+
1TTR rs28933981 c.416C>T T/CMISDamaging 0.00147439433154AMYLOIDOSIS, HEREDITARY, TRANSTHYRETIN-RELATED, MODIFIER OF|Cardiomyopathy|Amyloidogenic transthyretin amyloidosis|Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease|not specified|Cardiovascular phenotype|not provided Conflicting interpretations of pathogenicity 13434 105210
NCBI gene: This gene encodes one of the three prealbumins, which include alpha-1-antitrypsin, transthyretin and orosomucoid. The encoded protein, transthyretin, is a homo-tetrameric carrier protein, which transports thyroid hormones in the plasma and cerebrospinal fluid. It is also involved in the transport of retinol (vitamin A) in the plasma by associating with retinol-binding protein. The protein may also be involved in other intracellular processes including proteolysis, nerve regeneration, autophagy and glucose homeostasis. Mutations in this gene are associated with amyloid deposition, predominantly affecting peripheral nerves or the heart, while a small percentage of the gene mutations are non-amyloidogenic. The mutations are implicated in the etiology of several diseases, including amyloidotic polyneuropathy, euthyroid hyperthyroxinaemia, amyloidotic vitreous opacities, cardiomyopathy, oculoleptomeningeal amyloidosis, meningocerebrovascular amyloidosis and carpal tunnel syndrome. [provided by RefSeq, Aug 2017]
+
2ATM rs1801516 c.5557G>A A/GMISDamaging 0.113437964997Hereditary breast ovarian cancer syndrome|Ataxia-telangiectasia syndrome|Hereditary cancer-predisposing syndrome|not specified|not provided Benign 128458 208900
NCBI gene: The protein encoded by this gene belongs to the PI3/PI4-kinase family. This protein is an important cell cycle checkpoint kinase that phosphorylates; thus, it functions as a regulator of a wide variety of downstream proteins, including tumor suppressor proteins p53 and BRCA1, checkpoint kinase CHK2, checkpoint proteins RAD17 and RAD9, and DNA repair protein NBS1. This protein and the closely related kinase ATR are thought to be master controllers of cell cycle checkpoint signaling pathways that are required for cell response to DNA damage and for genome stability. Mutations in this gene are associated with ataxia telangiectasia, an autosomal recessive disorder. [provided by RefSeq, Aug 2010]
+
3ATM rs1800058 c.4258C>T T/CMISDamaging 0.0111928723443Hereditary breast ovarian cancer syndrome|Malignant tumor of breast|Ataxia-telangiectasia syndrome|Hereditary cancer-predisposing syndrome|not specified|Breast and/or ovarian cancer|not provided Conflicting interpretations of pathogenicity 128456 208900
NCBI gene: The protein encoded by this gene belongs to the PI3/PI4-kinase family. This protein is an important cell cycle checkpoint kinase that phosphorylates; thus, it functions as a regulator of a wide variety of downstream proteins, including tumor suppressor proteins p53 and BRCA1, checkpoint kinase CHK2, checkpoint proteins RAD17 and RAD9, and DNA repair protein NBS1. This protein and the closely related kinase ATR are thought to be master controllers of cell cycle checkpoint signaling pathways that are required for cell response to DNA damage and for genome stability. Mutations in this gene are associated with ataxia telangiectasia, an autosomal recessive disorder. [provided by RefSeq, Aug 2010]

Lipid Metabolism

+
# RSIDGeneRisk AlleleGenotypePubmed ID PopulationP-ValueWeight
+
1 rs268 LPL G GG[PMID 22399527]; [PMID: 20429872]; [PMID 16741292]; [PMID 16651467];European; 2,00E-12-1.0
Conclusion: LPL is an enzyme that plays a key role in the breakdown and utilization of fats in the body. rs268, also known as LPL Asn291Ser as well as LPL N291S or N318S, a SNP in the lipoprotein lipase LPL gene, has been linked to increased susceptibility to hypertriglyceridemia, heart disease, Type-2 diabetes, idiopathic venous thromboembolism. This mutation has been shown to alter LPL activity and increase the risk of hypertriglyceridemia, a condition characterized by high levels of triglycerides in the blood. It's important to note that the impact of the N291S mutation on lipid metabolism and the risk of metabolic disorders can vary depending on other genetic and environmental factors.
Genotype specific conclusion: GG genotype carriers may have a decreased activity of LPL and increased risk for venous thromboembolism (3x increased according to the [PMID 16651467]). This genotype is a risk factor for dyslipidemia, characterized by hypertriglyceridemia and low HDL-C levels. This LPL gene variant predisposes to more severe dyslipidemia with increasing age and weight gain [PMID: 16741292]. It's important to note that the impact of the rs268 mutation on lipid metabolism and the risk of metabolic disorders can vary depending on other genetic and environmental factors.
Study design: Discovery sample description: 2,637 European ancestry cases, 7,927 European ancestry controls Discovery ancestry (country of recruitment): 10564 European (Finland)
+
2 rs676210 APOB G GG[PMID: 26629186]; [PMID: 34156559]; [PMID: 23247145]European, Chinese; 6,00E-197-1.0
Conclusion: Encodes the apolipoprotein B protein, which is a major component of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol. Mutations in this gene have been associated with high LDL cholesterol levels and an increased risk of heart disease. Apolipoprotein B (apoB), a key component of VLDL particles and microsomal triacylglycerol transfer protein (MTP), plays an important role in lipid metabolism. Reduced secretion of apoB protein can result in reduced production of chylomicron and VLDL and then leading to malabsorption of fats and fat-soluble vitamins. This SNP was shown to affect atorvastatin response among Iraqi population: in response to 40 mg/day of atorvastatin therapy, the minor allele (A) observed a greater LDL-C lowering than the wild type allele (G) [PMID: 34156559]. This SNP was shown to have association with Acute Coronary Syndrome in Mexican population [PMID: 35440891].
Genotype specific conclusion: G allele is unfavourable. Carriers of G allele have elevated risk of hyperlipidemia. AG and GG genotypes were shown to be associated with hyperlipidemia in in the Chinese Yugur population [PMID: 28902930]. A GWAS study by AtheroRemo Consortium showed AG and GG genotypes are more likely to have elevated LDL level, but not cardiovascular events [PMID: 23247145]
Study design: Discovery sample description: 441,016 European ancestry individuals Discovery ancestry (country of recruitment): 441016 European (NR)
+
3 rs328 LPL G GG[PMID: 18193044]; [PMID: 30944368]; [PMID: 19148283];European; African 2,00E-28-0.8
Conclusion: The LPL gene provides instructions for making the enzyme lipoprotein lipase, which breaks down fats in the body. To be precise it is responsible for the hydrolysis of triglycerides and very low-density lipoproteins (VLDL). A particular variant of the LPL gene, called rs328, has been studied for its potential associations with various health conditions. This SNP is also called LPL 1595C>G or LPL Ser447X. The S447X mutation is a variant in the LPL (lipoprotein lipase) gene that results in a deficiency of functional LPL enzyme. This mutation has been associated with impaired lipid metabolism and an increased risk of certain metabolic disorders. Individuals with the S447X mutation may have high levels of triglycerides in their blood, which can increase the risk of pancreatitis and other health problems. This mutation may also increase the risk of developing coronary artery disease, a condition in which the arteries that supply blood to the heart become narrowed or blocked. The S447X mutation is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, which means that a person must inherit two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent) to have the condition. Individuals with only one copy of the mutated gene are called carriers and do not typically have any symptoms or health problems related to the mutation. It's important to note that the impact of the S447X mutation on lipid metabolism and the risk of metabolic disorders can vary depending on other genetic and environmental factors.
Genotype specific conclusion: You have an unfavourable variant of S447X (rs328) LPL polymorphism. That incrase risk of having high levels of triglycerides in blood. This mutation may also increase the risk of developing coronary artery disease, a condition in which the arteries that supply blood to the heart become narrowed or blocked. It have to mentioned, that risk of metabolic disorders can vary depending on other genetic and environmental factors.
Study design: Discovery sample description: 2,758 European ancestry individuals Discovery ancestry (country of recruitment): 2758 European (NR)
+
4 rs6544713 ABCG8 T TT[PMID: 30926973];European; African; Asian; Latin American; 3,00E-24-0.8
Conclusion: The ABCG8 gene provides instructions for making a protein called ATP-binding cassette transporter G8. This protein is involved in the transport of cholesterol and other lipids within cells, and it plays a role in the regulation of lipid levels in the body. Studies have suggested that the ABCG8 protein may be involved in the breakdown of cholesterol in the liver and the removal of excess cholesterol from the body. Variations in the ABCG8 gene may be associated with changes in cholesterol metabolism and an increased risk of certain health conditions, such as hypercholesterolemia (high cholesterol) and cardiovascular disease. This SNP is associated with an increased risk of Coronary Artery Disease, Carotid Artery Disease, Ischemic Stroke and Diabetes.
Genotype specific conclusion: The allele T of this SNP is associated with increased LDL cholesterol. TT genotype is associated with increased LDL cholesterol risk.
Study design: Discovery sample description: up to 23,353 African ancestry individuals, 13,171 Asian ancestry individuals, up to 82,522 European ancestry individuals, 6,646 Hispanic individuals; Discovery ancestry (country of recruitment): 6646 Hispanic or Latin American (NR), 82522 European (NR), 13171 Asian unspecified (NR), 23353 African unspecified (NR)
+
5 rs7679 PCIF1 C CC[PMID: 19060906]; [PMID: 19965587];European; 7,00E-11-0.8
Conclusion: The PCIF1 gene provides instructions for making a protein called PCI domain-containing family 1 protein. This protein is involved in the regulation of lipid (fat) metabolism and energy homeostasis in the body. Studies have suggested that the PCIF1 protein may be involved in the breakdown and storage of fats, as well as in the regulation of cholesterol and triglyceride levels in the blood. Variations in the PCIF1 gene may be associated with changes in lipid metabolism and an increased risk of certain health conditions, such as obesity and metabolic syndrome.
Genotype specific conclusion: The minor allele C was associated with decreased HDL cholesterol and increased triglycerides. Your genotype CC is associated with lipid profile disturbance risk.
Study design: Discovery sample description: 19,840 European ancestry individuals Discovery ancestry (country of recruitment): 19840 European (Finland, Sweden, U.S., Italy, U.K., France);
+
6 rs2650000 HNF1A-AS1 A AA[PMID: 28035729]; [PMID 19060906];European; Chinese; 2,00E-08-0.8
Conclusion: The HNF1A-AS1 gene provides instructions for making a noncoding RNA molecule called HNF1A antisense RNA 1. Noncoding RNAs do not provide instructions for making proteins, but they play important regulatory roles in the body. The function of HNF1A-AS1 is not fully understood, but research has suggested that it may play a role in lipid (fat) metabolism and energy homeostasis in the body.
Genotype specific conclusion: A allele is a risk allele, and is associated with incresead LDL. AA genotype is associated with increased risk of elevated LDL level.
Study design: Discovery sample description: 19,840 European ancestry individuals Discovery ancestry (country of recruitment): 19840 European (Finland, Sweden, U.S., Italy, U.K., France)
+
7 rs1800961 HNF4A T TT[PMID: 24097068]; [PMID: 18660489]; [PMID: 30698716];European; 2,00E-34-0.8
Conclusion: HNF4A (Hepatocyte nuclear factor 4 alpha) is a transcription factor that plays a key role in the regulation of hepatic (liver) gene expression. HNF4A has been shown to be involved in the regulation of lipid metabolism, specifically the synthesis and metabolism of cholesterol and lipoproteins in the liver. HNF4A has also been linked to the development of metabolic disorders such as diabetes and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). Mutations in the HNF4A gene have been associated with an increased risk of developing these disorders.
Genotype specific conclusion: The minor allele of this SNP (T) was associated with decreased HDL ("good") cholesterol, so is a risk allele. Alcohol consumption has a negative impact on cholesterole level for T-allele carriers [PMID: 30698716]
Study design: Discovery sample description: 94,595 European ancestry individuals Discovery ancestry (country of recruitment): 94595 European (NR)
+
8 rs12740374 CELSR2 T TT[PMID: 18262040]; [PMID: 25350695]; [PMID: 28577571];European; African; 2,00E-26-0.8
Conclusion: CELSR2 and PSRC1 are mapped to the same locus as the SORT1 gene. The SORT1 gene encodes sortilin which is involved in the cholesterol homeostasis in humans. Sortilin increases the hepatic output of VLDL which acts as a precursor for LDL in plasma. GWAS study showed minor allele is associated with increased LDL [PMID: 18262040]; Pharmacogenetic meta-analysis of genome-wide association studies of LDL cholesterol response to statins found each minor allele to increase statin effectiveness [PMID: 25350695];
Genotype specific conclusion: TT genotype is associated with increased risk of LDL elevation, but the better response to statins.
Study design: Reported trait: LDL cholesterol levels Genotyping technology: Genome-wide genotyping array, Genome-wide sequencing Discovery sample description: 14,126 African ancestry individuals Discovery ancestry (country of recruitment): 14126 Sub-Saharan African (Kenya, Uganda, South Africa, Ghana, Nigeria)
+
9 rs471364 TTC39B C CC[PMID 21738485]; [PMID 19951432]; [PMID: 19060906];European; 3,00E-10-0.7
Conclusion: The tetratricopeptide repeat domain 39B gene (TTC39B), also known as C9orf52, a high density lipoprotein (HDL) gene discovered in human genome wide association studies (GWASes).
Genotype specific conclusion: C-allele is associated with lower levels of "good" HDL cholesrterol, so C allele is considered as a risk allele.
Study design: Genotyping technologyGenome-wide genotyping array Discovery sample description: 19,840 European ancestry individuals Discovery ancestry (country of recruitment): 19840 European (Finland, Sweden, U.S., Italy, U.K., France)
+
10 rs6756629 ABCG8, ABCG5 G GG[PMID: 20832063]; [PMID:19060911];European; 3,00E-06-0.5
Conclusion: ABCG5/ABCG8 are key in regulating whole-body sterol trafficking, by eliminating sterols via the biliary tree as well as the intestinal tract. ABCG5/ABCG8 are genetically associated with lipid levels and downstream atherosclerotic disease, as well as formation of gallstones and the risk of gallbladder cancer.
Genotype specific conclusion: G allele is a risk allele. You genotype is associated with increased risk of elevated LDL and TG.
Study design: Genotyping technology: Genome-wide genotyping array Discovery sample description: 17,083 European ancestry individuals, 714 Orcadian individuals Discovery ancestry (country of recruitment): 17797 European (Finland, Sweden, Australia, Italy, Netherlands, Germany, U.K., Croatia, Norway, Denmark)
+
11 rs2967605 RAB11B T TT[PMID: 29507422];European; 8,00E-09-0.3
Conclusion: RAB11B is a member of the RAB family of small GTPases, which play a role in intracellular membrane transport. RAB11B has been shown to be involved in the regulation of lipid metabolism, specifically the recycling of endocytosed lipoproteins in the lysosome. Dysregulation of RAB11B has been linked to the development of various diseases, including obesity and diabetes.
Genotype specific conclusion: The minor allele of this SNP (T) was associated with decreased HDL cholesterol, so is unfavourable. You are carrying two unfavourable alleles of this SNP.
Study design: Discovery sample description: 76,627 European ancestry individuals, 7,795 Hispanic individuals, 6,855 East Asian ancestry individuals, 2,958 African American individuals, 439 South Asian ancestry individuals Discovery ancestry (country of recruitment): 76627 European (NR), 7795 Hispanic or Latin American (NR), 2958 African American or Afro-Caribbean (NR), 439 South Asian (NR)

Thrombophilia

+
# RSIDGeneRisk AlleleGenotypePubmed ID PopulationP-ValueWeight
+
1 rs1801133 MTHFR A AG[PMID: 30466296]; [PMID: 20031578]; [PMID: 34707639];European; East Asians; West Asians; [PMID: 20031578]: 8 x 10-35; [PMID: 34707639]: 4 x 10-104;-1.3
Conclusion: Gene product is envolved in the folate metabolism. Polymorphisms are associated with elevated homocysteine risk, folic acid and B12 deficiency. For the rs1801133 polymorphism, significant association with the risk of venous thromboembolism was found. Further subgroup analyses according to ethnicity of participants revealed that the rs1801133 polymorphism was significantly associated with the risk of venous thromboembolism in Caucasians, East Asians, and West Asians [PMID: 30466296].
Genotype specific conclusion: GA variant is associated with increased risk of hyperhomocysteinemia and thrombophilia.
Study design: [PMID: 20031578] 13,974 European ancestry females [PMID: 34707639] 5,175 Han Chinese ancestry individuals
